My clothing choices run the gamut. Sartorial misadventures notwithstanding, I've noticed that I am treated differently--sometimes vastly differently--depending on the image I'm currently projecting. This goes beyond merely my clothes, but they are certainly the focus.

I'm a lawyer by day, so it[.] not surprising that people address me as "sir" around the building (since most people in my building who are not members of the bar seem to automatically assume anyone with a suit on is an attorney and therefore of some importance). But that extends beyond my building--if I stop at a store on the way home, I am also typically addressed as "sir" and treated deferentially.

When I take off the suit, things change. I reside in a small town with an expensive, private liberal_arts school that tends to attract financially advantaged families from the Northeastern U_S. The residents of the town seem to have an uneasy relationship with the student body. 

If I head into the same stores that I was just describing without my suit on, people[.] perception of me seems to change drastically. The fact that I tend toward a prep sort of look in my casual wear seems to exacerbate the problem. For the last several months, I've been testing it out--quite unscientifically, of course--by wandering around the local grocery store. If I am suited up and need to walk past someone in an aisle and say "excuse me," they nearly always acknowledge it in some manner--either by saying something to the effect of "no problem" or a quick head nod. If they walk past me as I am checking a shelf, I nearly always get an "excuse me" from them. When I am not wearing a suit, its as though the local populace won't even acknowledge my presence. I've come to assume it[.] because they believe me to be a local college student. 

Ridiculous, I know. But I enjoy this little game I've been playing around town.
